generif.text: fragment of the HMGN2 protein homes to the nuclei of tumor cells and tumor endothelial cells and tumor endothelial cells in vivo
A polypeptide, HMGN2, was isolated and may be an antimicrobial effector molecule of mononuclear leukocytes.
These studies demonstrate that the mode of binding of HMGNs to chromatin is cell cycle dependent.
each of the 4 amino acids in the R-S-RL motif are the only residues absolutely essential for anchoring HMGN protein to nucleosomes, both in vivo and in vitro.
HMGN1 (HMG14) and HMGN2 (HMG17) potently repress ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling by four different molecular motor proteins.
HMGN2 protein has antimicrobial activity and is probably involved in innate immunity in vivo.
HMGN2 acts as a positive modulator of nuclear factor kappaB signalling to promote lipopolysaccharide-induced beta-defensin-2 expression.
HMGN2 binds to both the acidic patch in the histone H2A-H2B dimer and to nucleosomal DNA near the entry/exit point, "stapling" the histone core and the DNA.
The association of the PRLr with HMGN2 enables Stat5a-responsive promoter binding, thus facilitating transcriptional activation and promoting anchorage-independent growth.
HMGN2 is a bona fide Aurora B substrate in vivo and show that its dynamic association to chromatin is controlled by Aurora B.

HMGN2 is modified by covalent attachment of small ubiquitin-related modifier 1 (SUMO1) by pro-inflammatory signal and identified the major SUMOylated lysine residues that localize to the HMGN2 nucleosome-binding domain at Lys-17 and Lys-35.
HMGN2 is an anti-tumor effector molecule of CD8 T cells.
Data show that chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) cells present high-mobility group nucleosome-binding protein 2 (HMGN2) at membrane.
enhanced expression of HMGN2 in osteosarcoma cells by HMGN2 lentivirus, exerts inhibitory effects on growth and migration of osteosarcoma cells.
Results provide evidence that HDAC6 could regulate HMGN2 acetylation levels and binding to Stat5a-responsive promoters, and therefore, Stat5a transcriptional activity in breast cancer cells.

Data show that high mobility group nucleosomal binding domain 2 (HMGN2) knockdown induced the increased expression of alpha5beta1 integrin on cell membranes, which resulted in a significant increase in Klebsiella pneumoniae internalization.

elucidate a novel mechanism whereby the linker histone H1 prevents STAT5 binding at promoter DNA, and the PRL-induced dissociation of H1 mediated by HMGN2 is necessary to allow full STAT5 recruitment and promote the biological effects of PRL signaling

these results uncover a novel link between nuclear protein HMGN2 and Nrf2-mediated cellular redox circumstance and suggest roles of HMGN2 in autonomous immune response to Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection
HMGN1 and HMGN2 remodel core and linker histone tail domains within chromatin.
This study suggests that HMGN2 is an antitumor effector molecule of gammadeltaT cells.

Urinary tract infection is one of the most common bacterial infections which is mainly caused by Escherichia coli (UPEC). HMGN2 expression is elevated in bladder epithelial cell line 5637 (BEC 5637). HMGN2 induces autophagy in BEC 5637 via AMPK/ULK1 pathway.  Viable UPEC J96 suppresses autophagy in BEC 5637. HMGN2 boosts UPEC J96 proliferation in BEC 5637.
High-mobility group nucleosomal binding domain 2 protects against microcephaly by maintaining global chromatin accessibility during corticogenesis.
Transcriptomic analysis of peripheral blood mononuclear cells in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma patients.
High mobility group nucleosomal binding 2 reduces integrin alpha5/beta1-mediated adhesion of Klebsiella pneumoniae on human pulmonary epithelial cells via nuclear factor I.
Prognostic value of HMGN family expression in acute myeloid leukemia.
Prolactin Drives a Dynamic STAT5A/HDAC6/HMGN2 Cis-Regulatory Landscape Exploitable in ER+ Breast Cancer.

BP.term: killing of cells of another organism
antimicrobial humoral immune response mediated by antimicrobial peptide

name: high mobility group nucleosomal binding domain 2
other_names: high mobility group nucleosome-binding domain-containing protein 2
summary: The protein encoded by this gene binds nucleosomal DNA and is associated with transcriptionally active chromatin. Along with a similar protein, HMGN1, the encoded protein may help maintain an open chromatin configuration around transcribable genes. The protein has also been found to have antimicrobial activity against bacteria, viruses and fungi. [provided by RefSeq, Oct 2014].
